description: CO2 emission per unit of value added

definition.label: Definition
definition.content:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) emission per unit of value added is a ratio indicator between carbon dioxide emissions and value added. 
The indicator CO2 emission per unit of value added is currently being measured by CO2 emission per GDP PPP.

rationale.label: Rationale
rationale.content: Carbon dioxide (CO2) emission per unit of value added is a universal indicator for measuring the impact of industrial production on environment. It captures the intensity of energy use, energy efficiency of production technology and most importantly use of fossil fuels.

concepts.label: Concepts
concepts.content: Carbon dioxide (CO2) emission accounts for around 80% of all GHG emission from the manufacturing processes. This is an important measure not only for emission but also for use and type of energy consumed. CO2 emission refers to mainly fossil fuel based energy. This measure reflects the progress made by countries from fossil-fuel based to renewable energy sources. Data can be aggregated to country groups and dis-aggregated by industry sector

comments_and_limitations.label: Comments and limitations
comments_and_limitations.content: Collection of energy and emission data is not systematized in many countries. National data source can be statistical office, Energy Departments and Environment agencies. Energy consumption data and value added data are coming from different data sources which may encounter the compatibility problem.

computation_method.label: Computation Method
computation_method.content:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions are estimated from data on energy consumption.It is computed as: amount of CO2 emission (in physical measurement unit such as tonne) divided by value added (in US$)
This indicator can also be presented as CO2 emission per unit of output.

disaggregation.label: Disaggregation
disaggregation.content: Data can be presented by industry; by country group

treatment_of_missing_values_at_country_l.label: Treatment of missing values at country level
treatment_of_missing_values_at_country_l.content: A methodological guideline on imputation method exists which can be shared with IAEG-SDG

treatment_of_missing_values_at_regional_.label: Treatment of missing values at regional and global levels
treatment_of_missing_values_at_regional_.content: No imputation is allowed if a the value is missing for entire country or region. It can only be projected from the data reported for the previous years.

regional_aggregates.label: Regional aggregates
regional_aggregates.content: Global and regional estimated are derived from the total of countries in the country group. Weights are implicit.

sources_of_discrepancies.label: Sources of discrepancies
sources_of_discrepancies.content: Difference may arise 1) if the country has not submitted energy consumption data adequately dis-aggregated by sector or by energy sources 2) due to conversion of value data into USD

description.label: Description
description.content: Energy consumption and value added data are available for more than 150 countries from UNIDO database and UNSD energy database as well as International Energy Agency (IEA) database. Emission data are directly reported by NSOs in many cases.

list.label: List
list.content: UNIDO database; UNSD energy database; IEA database; NSOs (emmissions data)

collection_process.label: Collection process
collection_process.content: UNIDO Data collection is carried out regularly through General industrial statistics questionnaire

description.label: Description
description.content: Energy consumption and value added data are available for more than 150 countries from UNIDO MVA database and UNSD energy database as well as International Energy Agency (IEA) database

data_collection.label: Data collection
data_collection.content: Data collection is carried out by receiving data electronically throughout the year.

data_release.label: Data release
data_release.content: Data are updated annually. New release generally takes place around March April. (March/April 2017)
